name: TAXES AND BUS STRATEGY

values.comments:
Accounting 897, Taxes and Business Strategy, aims to develop a framework for understanding how taxes affect business decisions. Traditional finance and strategy courses do not consider the role of taxes. Similarly, traditional tax courses often ignore the richness of the decision context in which tax factors operate. They key themes of the framework- all parties, all taxes, and all costs- are applied to decision contexts such as investments, compensation, organizational form, regulated industries, financial instruments, tax-sheltered investments, mergers and acquisitions, multinational, and multistate. The ultimate goal is to provide a new approach to thinking about taxes (and all forms of government intervention) that will be valuable even as laws and governments change. 
	Overall, students commented that this course was “great,” and although difficult, it was “extremely useful information.” Some student even commented that this class was “one of the best they took at Wharton.” The course offered “a great overview of corporate tax issues.” The information was “practical” “challenging” and “relevant.”
	Students regarded Professor Blouin as “fantastic” and knowledgeable about the course material. One student commented, “she knows the material cold, uses great examples to get her point across and is able to capture interest.” Another student complimented Professor Blouin’s ability to “[take] a fairly dry topic and [teach] it with such enthusiasm and interesting examples.”
	This is an MBA Course and auditors need permission.
